channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Live Updates: Putin Orders Forces to Ukraine’s Separatist Enclaves
item.description: The U.S. and E.U. said they would begin imposing limited sanctions. The United Nations Security Council is holding an emergency meeting.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: A column of Russian armored vehicles, military trucks and supply units about 60 miles away from the border with Ukraine on Monday.

item.title: Colombia Decriminalizes Abortion
item.description: The decision by the Constitutional Court comes in the wake of similar moves in Mexico and Argentina.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Nathalia Angarita for The New York Times

item.title: For Ukraine’s Jews, the Threat of War Stirs Memories of Past Horrors
item.description: In Odessa, Jewish leaders are preparing for the worst: hiring security guards, scoping out bomb shelters and making plans to evacuate if Russia invades the country.
item.dc:creator: Michael Schwirtz
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Prayer services following shabbat at the Great Choral Synagogue in Odessa, Ukraine.

item.title: Japan Wants to Showcase Gold Mines’ History. Just Not All of It.
item.description: A bid for a UNESCO World Heritage designation is the latest flash point between Japan and South Korea over Japanese colonial abuses during World War II.
item.dc:creator: Motoko Rich and Hikari Hida
item.category: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization
item.media:credit: Shiho Fukada for The New York Times
item.media:description: A gold and silver mine on Sado Island, Japan. Mines on the island once supplied the shoguns of Japan with precious metals.

item.title: In an Uneven Fight With China, Lithuania's Brand Becomes Toxic
item.description: After Lithuania dared to seek closer ties with Taiwan, China cut off trade — even blocking imports of products from other countries with Lithuanian parts.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:credit: Andrej Vasilenko for The New York Times
item.media:description: Brolis Group, a chip maker in Lithuania, recently scrapped plans to build a $50 million factory at home, mindful that foreign customers want to avoid ending up on China’s blacklist.

item.title: Arab Rulers and Spy Chiefs Stashed Millions in Swiss Bank
item.description: A leak of account data from Credit Suisse revealed the holdings of powerful figures across the Middle East, raising new questions about self-dealing.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard
item.media:description: Sultan Qaboos bin Said of Oman, pictured in 2005, had two Credit Suisse accounts, one that held nearly $126 million in 2003 and another that held $57 million in 2015, according to the data leak.

item.title: ‘We Have All Gone Into Debt’: Soaring Bills Deepen Crisis for Turks
item.description: Hit by spiraling inflation, electricity bills have doubled for households and businesses in only a month.
item.dc:creator: Carlotta Gall
item.media:description: A bar in Istanbul on Wednesday. The cost of power has doubled in some parts of Turkey, fueling widespread discontent.

item.title: Boris Johnson Moves to Lift Coronavirus Restrictions in England
item.description: The British prime minister is shifting toward a strategy of living with Covid-19. Critics argue that the move is too soon, even as case numbers fall.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Coronavirus checks outside a West End theater in London in December.

item.title: Was Canada Trucker Protest a Blip, or the Start of Something Bigger?
item.description: The demonstrators were passionate, organized and supported financially, but such spontaneous movements often have a tough time converting their energy into real change.
item.dc:creator: Natalie Kitroeff and Ian Austen
item.media:credit: Brett Gundlock for The New York Times
item.media:description: Protesters near Parliament Hill in Ottawa earlier this month.

item.title: France Installs Sensors on Streets to Tackle 'Noise From Hell'
item.description: The French authorities are installing “sound radars” in some cities to detect and photograph vehicles making excessive noise, which they say is a public health hazard.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.media:description: Traffic on the Champs-Élysées in Paris. Residents say that motorcycles and modified scooters are among the worst offenders when it comes to noise.

item.title: Risking Their Lives, for Little Pay, to Guard India’s Forests
item.description: Braving tigers and other dangers, frontline workers face difficult working conditions as they try to keep the peace between humans and wildlife.
item.dc:creator: Shalini Venugopal Bhagat and Atul Loke
item.media:credit: Atul Loke for The New York Times
item.media:description: Forest rangers driving toward a field post in Wayanad, India.

item.title: How Europeans Are Responding to Exorbitant Gas and Power Bills
item.description: High energy prices in Europe are upending people’s lives. While some are installing solar panels, others are stoking their wood-burning stoves.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Eddy and Liz Alderman
item.media:credit: Katrin Streicher for The New York Times
item.media:description: Some people are now using wood to heat their homes.

item.title: Queen Elizabeth Tests Positive for Covid-19, as England Moves to Relax Rules
item.description: The queen, who recently marked her 70th anniversary on the throne, has faced a series of health issues since late last year.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:description: Queen Elizabeth II this month at Sandringham House in Norfolk, England. Buckingham Palace said on Sunday that she was “experiencing mild coldlike symptoms.”

item.title: India’s Congress Party Faces a Test of Survival as Punjab Votes
item.description: A defeat here, one of the few states where the once-dominant party still retains power, would be a major blow.
item.dc:creator: Mujib Mashal and Hari Kumar
item.media:credit: Saumya Khandelwal for The New York Times
item.media:description: Charanjit Singh Channi arriving for a Congress party meeting in Jhabal Kalan, India, on Thursday. He is seeking election to the position he was appointed to, chief minister of Punjab.

item.title: Putin Calls Ukrainian Statehood a Fiction. History Suggests Otherwise.
item.description: In a speech, President Vladimir V. Putin bent Ukraine’s complex history into his own version that served as a justification for his cleaving off more of its territory.
item.dc:creator: Michael Schwirtz, Maria Varenikova and Rick Gladstone
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: People in Odessa on Sunday commemorated protesters killed in 2014 by paramilitary police forces in Kyiv, Ukraine.

item.title: U.S. Offers Limited Initial Response to Russia as It Weighs Stiffer Sanctions
item.description: President Biden faces the challenge of maintaining unity with allies as he seeks to balance deterrence and punishment in dealing with President Vladimir Putin of Russia.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear and David E. Sanger
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia signing documents recognizing the independence of separatist regions in eastern Ukraine on Monday. He then ordered Russian troops into those areas.

item.title: Putin Orders Forces to Russia-Backed Ukraine Regions and Hints at Wider Military Aims
item.description: The moves by the Russian leader were his most blatant yet in a confrontation with the West that threatens to escalate into the biggest military action in Europe since World War II.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski, Valerie Hopkins and Steven Erlanger
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Kristina Makarenko, 24, sitting in a shelter with her two-year-old son, Anton, after hearing news that more shelling might be imminent Monday in the eastern Ukrainian village of Vrubivka.

item.title: Israel Says Police Didn’t Hack Civilians Without Court Approval
item.description: An official investigation refuted claims that the police had illegally hacked dozens of civilians using spyware from NSO Group, an Israeli company that has long attracted global scrutiny.
item.dc:creator: Ronen Bergman and Patrick Kingsley
item.media:description: The NSO Group logo on a wall of a building next to one of the company’s branches in southern Israel.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing: Putin Recognizes Separatists in Ukraine
item.description: Western officials warn that Russia is paving a path toward war.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Cullen

item.title: Highlights From Putin's Address on Breakaway Regions in Ukraine
item.description: President Vladimir V. Putin said he would recognize the independence of two Russia-backed territories in eastern Ukraine. Here are highlights from his 40-minute speech.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins
item.media:description: A woman in St. Petersburg, Russia, watching President Vladimir Putin address the nation on Monday.

item.title: On the ground: A column of Russian vehicles, and soldiers without insignia.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: A column of Russian armored vehicles, military trucks and supply units about 60 miles away from the border with Ukraine on Monday.

item.title: In Photos: Eastern Ukraine on Monday.
Boris Johnson warns that Russia is planning the biggest war in Europe since 1945.
item.dc:creator: Dan Bilefsky
item.media:credit: Emile Ducke for The New York Times
item.media:description: Russian and Belarusian soldiers during joint exercises near Baranovichi, Belarus, on Saturday.

item.title: Paul Farmer, Pioneer of Global Health, Dies at 62
item.description: As a medical student, Dr. Farmer decided to build a clinic in Haiti. It grew into a vast network serving some of the world’s poorest communities.
item.dc:creator: Ellen Barry and Alex Traub
item.media:description: Dr. Paul Farmer speaking with an H.I.V. patient, Altagrace Cenatus, at a Partners in Health hospital in Haiti in 2003. He worked to provide quality health care to some of the poorest people in the world.

item.title: Why Donetsk and Luhansk, in Donbas Region, Matter in Ukraine
item.description: The act of recognition is fraught with meaning because the borders claimed by the Russia-backed leaders of the two breakaway regions extend into space controlled by the Ukrainian army.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins and Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: A woman at the border crossing between Russia and the separatist Donetsk People’s Republic in Avilo-Uspenka, Russia, on Saturday.

item.title: U.S. Troops in Poland Brace for Possible Ukrainian Evacuees
item.description: Tens of thousands of people, including Americans, could flee across the border if Russia launches a full invasion of Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: U.S. Army soldiers in the 82nd Airborne Division in Poland near the Ukranian border on Monday.

item.title: Got a Covid Booster? You Probably Won’t Need Another for a Long Time
item.description: A flurry of new studies suggest that several parts of the immune system can mount a sustained, potent response to any coronavirus variant.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli
item.media:description: A colored transmission electron micrograph of a T cell. Antibodies are relatively easy to study, whereas analyzing immune cells requires blood, skill, special equipment and lots of time.

item.title: U.S. still sees an invasion as imminent, dimming hopes for a Biden-Putin summit.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear, David E. Sanger and Steven Erlanger
item.media:description: A Ukrainian army frontline position in Krymske, in eastern Ukraine.

item.title: 21uk
item.dc:creator: Cora Engelbrecht and Emma Bubola
item.media:credit: Tom Brenner for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian demonstrators protesting against Russia outside the White House on Sunday.

item.title: Putin says Russia will decide on Monday whether to recognize breakaway regions.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins and Anton Troianovski
item.media:description: Russian President Vladimir V. Putin chairing a meeting with members of the Security Council in Moscow on Monday.

item.title: Air France, Lufthansa and SAS Limit Flights to Ukraine
item.description: Lufthansa and Scandinavian Airlines also canceled flights to Kyiv as fears grow of a Russian invasion.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola and Roger Cohen
item.media:description: An Air France plane landing at Paris Charles de Gaulle airport in December.

item.title: Why Ukraine Is Different
item.description: A Russian invasion of Ukraine would be unlike most wars in 80 years.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:description: A Ukrainian Army soldier in eastern Ukraine.

item.title: France says Biden and Putin agree to meet in ‘principle,’ but obstacles remain.
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen
item.media:description: President Biden and President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia at their first meeting, in Geneva, in June.

item.title: Six Days Afloat in the Everglades
item.description: After a storm disrupted plans for a 99-mile paddling trek, a Times journalist’s time on the water took a more reflective turn. Come look and listen alongside him.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Hiltner

item.title: In an Arctic Outpost, Friday Nights Are for Curling
item.description: In a town with one stoplight, 120 miles above the Arctic Circle, curling provides women with a reason to leave their houses. And that is no small thing.
item.dc:creator: Hilary Swift and Ellen Barry
item.media:credit: Hilary Swift for The New York Times
item.media:description: Tyra Bain, 15, practicing at the Curling Center in Inuvik, a town in the Northwest Territories of Canada, during her school lunch break. Curling gets people to leave their houses during the darkest months of the year, when some might feel an inclination to stay home and withdraw.

item.title: 1897: Queen Victoria’s Diamond Jubilee Proposals
item.description: The plans to celebrate the 60th anniversary of the British monarch’s accession included a service at St. Paul’s Cathedral.
item.dc:creator: The International Herald Tribune

item.title: Russia is poised on Ukraine’s border after a weekend of shelling and evacuations in the east.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins
item.media:description: A Ukraine Army front line position in Krymske, in the Luhansk Oblast of eastern Ukraine, where mortar attacks continued this weekend.

item.title: U.S. Says Russia Has a List of Ukrainians to Kill or Detain
item.description: A U.S. ambassador cited “credible information” that Russian forces have compiled a list of Ukrainians to be targeted after an invasion.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong, Julian E. Barnes and Anton Troianovski
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: A march in Odessa, Ukraine, on Sunday marked the eighth anniversary of the 2014 protests that led to the ouster of President Viktor F. Yanukovych, an ally of President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing
item.description: Putin’s plan to invade Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Ukrainian Army solders patrol the front line near Luhansk, in eastern Ukraine.

item.title: At a pro-Ukraine rally, priests pray for the dead and diplomats hope for peace.
item.dc:creator: John Ismay
item.media:credit: Samuel Corum for The New York Times
item.media:description: Oksana Markarova, Kyiv’s ambassador to the United States, addressing a rally on Sunday in support of Ukraine at the Lincoln Memorial in Washington.

item.title: Putin’s Security Council meets as the Kremlin warns that ‘tensions are rising.’
item.description: The United States says Russia stands poised to attack Ukraine amid a frantic diplomatic push.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski
item.media:description: Russian President Vladimir V. Putin chairing a meeting with members of the Security Council via a video link last week in Moscow.

item.title: If war ignites in Ukraine, two little enclaves could be the spark.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Yana Tinyakova watches her son David, 12, shoot his new bb-gun from their front door as incoming and outgoing artillery fire continued around them in Luhansk, Ukraine, on Saturday. Ms. Tinyakova said the artillery has been constant the last several days but they have decided to stay in the area for now.

item.title: If War Flames in Ukraine, These 2 Little Enclaves May Be the Spark
item.description: Russian-backed separatists in the Luhansk and Donetsk regions once got just passing attention. They loom much larger now as many fear what may come next in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Gleb Yegorov, 17, at the bus station in Stanytsia Luhanska, Ukraine, on Sunday. He said he left separatist eastern Ukraine to avoid being drafted.

item.title: Satellite Images Show New Phase of Russian Military Readiness
item.description: Several units or troops have been deployed outside bases or training grounds, as Russian forces continue moving closer to the border with Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Christoph Koettl

item.title: Israel to Open Borders to Unvaccinated Tourists
item.description: After weathering the Omicron wave, the country is turning to testing to try to let in more visitors safely.
item.dc:creator: Ada Petriczko
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Tsafrir Abayov/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Starting March 1, Prime Minister Naftali Bennett will allow foreign tourists into Israel regardless of vaccine status.

item.title: Russia May Be Seeking Pretext for Ukraine Invasion, Officials Say
item.description: The pressure on Kyiv mounted after a weekend of shelling and evacuations in the east, and the extension of war games in neighboring Belarus.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins
item.category: Servant of the People (Ukrainian Political Party)
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Evacuees from the separatist-held region of eastern Ukraine on Sunday at a temporary shelter in Taganrog, Russia. Many were anxious about how long they might be displaced and about what might lie ahead.

item.title: Ukraine's Zelensky Accuses Western of Appeasement
item.description: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine reminded his Western counterparts of what was supposed to be an unforgettable lesson from Europe’s past.
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen
item.media:description: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine denounced the possibility of appeasing Russia in a speech on Saturday at the Munich Security Conference.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing: Shelling in Ukraine intensifies
item.description: Plus the Olympics end and Queen Elizabeth II tests positive.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain

item.title: Queen Elizabeth tests positive for the coronavirus, as England is poised to relax rules.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:description: Queen Elizabeth II is one of several people at Windsor Castle who are infected with the coronavirus, a palace official said.

item.title: What if Queen Elizabeth Were Too Ill to Carry Out Her Duties?
item.description: According to Buckingham Palace, if the queen needs to suspend her official duties because of illness or because she is abroad, two or more counselors of state can act on her behalf.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:description: Prince Charles and Prince William in November in Glasgow. Either could be called on to fill in for Queen Elizabeth II if she were unable to perform her duties.

item.title: Ukrainian Expats Express Solidarity With Homeland
item.description: At a rally in London, many of the attendees said they hoped that a full-scale Russian invasion could be averted.
item.dc:creator: Cora Engelbrecht
item.media:description: Demonstrators in London on Saturday showed support for Ukraine. The rally convened at the foot of a statue of Volodymyr the Great, a symbol of Ukrainian nationalism.

item.title: In a Call with Putin, Macron Pursues a Diplomatic Solution in Ukraine
item.description: But the Kremlin signaled little optimism regarding a diplomatic path, saying Western countries were pushing Ukraine’s government to a “military solution.”
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:description: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine, left, welcoming President Emmanuel Macron of France before their talks this month in Kyiv, Ukraine’s capital.

item.title: Data Leak Exposes How a Swiss Bank Served Strongmen and Spies
item.description: Leaked data on more than 18,000 accounts shows that the Swiss bank missed or ignored red flags.
item.dc:creator: Jesse Drucker and Ben Hubbard

item.title: Dead Body Is Pulled From Burning Ferry Off Greece, With 10 Still Missing
item.description: At least one person was confirmed to have died on the Euroferry Olympia, which caught fire on Friday and is still ablaze near the island of Corfu. Hundreds of others have been rescued.
item.dc:creator: Niki Kitsantonis
item.media:description: The Euroferry Olympia, near the Greek island of Corfu, on Sunday. The cause of the fire on the ship has not yet been established.

item.title: People From Eastern Ukraine Are Evacuating to Russia as Tensions Continue
item.description: Refugees crossed into Russia after a warning from Kremlin-backed rebel leaders that Ukraine was about to launch an attack on the separatist areas.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Refugees at a train station in Taganrog, Russia, on Sunday. They are part of a growing evacuation from eastern Ukraine.

item.title: Here’s how long Covid takes a toll on the body.
item.dc:creator: Josh Keller

item.title: Biden Is Still Willing to Talk to Putin, Blinken Says
item.description: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken said Russia was taking steps leading to an invasion of Ukraine — including keeping troops in Belarus — but the U.S. is still ready to engage in diplomacy.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong
item.media:description: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken at the Munich Security Conference in Germany on Saturday.
